author: Potter
text: Once upon a time there was an old cat, called Mrs. Tabitha Twitchit, who was an anxious parent.

author: Potter
text: She used to lose her kittens continually, and whenever they were lost they were always in mischief!

author: Potter
text: On baking day she determined to shut them up in a cupboard.

author: Potter
text: She caught Moppet and Mittens, but she could not find Tom.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tabitha went up and down all over the house, mewing for Tom Kitten.

author: Potter
text: She looked in the pantry under the staircase, and she searched the best spare bedroom that was all covered up with dust sheets.

author: Potter
text: She went right upstairs and looked into the attics, but she could not find him anywhere.

author: Potter
text: It was an old, old house, full of cupboards and passages.

author: Potter
text: Some of the walls were four feet thick, and there used to be queer noises inside them, as if there might be a little secret staircase.

author: Potter
text: Certainly there were odd little jagged doorways in the wainscot, and things disappeared at night-- especially cheese and bacon.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tabitha became more and more distracted and mewed dreadfully.

author: Potter
text: While their mother was searching the house, Moppet and Mittens had got into mischief.

author: Potter
text: The cupboard door was not locked, so they pushed it open and came out.

author: Potter
text: They went straight to the dough which was set to rise in a pan before the fire.

author: Potter
text: They patted it with their little soft paws--"Shall we make dear little muffins?" said Mittens to Moppet.

author: Potter
text: But just at that moment somebody knocked at the front door, and Moppet jumped into the flour barrel in a fright.

author: Potter
text: Mittens ran away to the dairy and hid in an empty jar on the stone shelf where the milk pans stand.

author: Potter
text: The visitor was a neighbor, Mrs. Ribby; she had called to borrow some yeast.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tabitha came downstairs mewing dreadfully--"Come in, Cousin Ribby, come in, and sit ye down!

author: Potter
text: I'm in sad trouble, Cousin Ribby," said Tabitha, shedding tears.

author: Potter
text: "I've lost my dear son Thomas; I'm afraid the rats have got him."

author: Potter
text: She wiped her eyes with her apron.

author: Potter
text: "He's a bad kitten, Cousin Tabitha; he made a cat's cradle of my best bonnet last time I came to tea.

author: Potter
text: Where have you looked for him?"

author: Potter
text: "All over the house!

author: Potter
text: The rats are too many for me.

author: Potter
text: What a thing it is to have an unruly family!" said Mrs. Tabitha Twitchit.

author: Potter
text: "I'm not afraid of rats; I will help you to find him; and whip him, too!

author: Potter
text: What is all that soot in the fender?"

author: Potter
text: "The chimney wants sweeping-- Oh, dear me, Cousin Ribby--now Moppet and Mittens are gone!

author: Potter
text: "They have both got out of the cupboard!"

author: Potter
text: Ribby and Tabitha set to work to search the house thoroughly again.

author: Potter
text: They poked under the beds with Ribby's umbrella and they rummaged in cupboards.

author: Potter
text: They even fetched a candle and looked inside a clothes chest in one of the attics.

author: Potter
text: They could not find anything, but once they heard a door bang and somebody scuttered downstairs.

author: Potter
text: "Yes, it is infested with rats," said Tabitha tearfully.

author: Potter
text: "I caught seven young ones out of one hole in the back kitchen, and we had them for dinner last Saturday.

author: Potter
text: And once I saw the old father rat--an enormous old rat-- Cousin Ribby.

author: Potter
text: I was just going to jump upon him, when he showed his yellow teeth at me and whisked down the hole.

author: Potter
text: "The rats get upon my nerves, Cousin Ribby," said Tabitha.

author: Potter
text: Ribby and Tabitha searched and searched.

author: Potter
text: They both heard a curious roly-poly noise under the attic floor.

author: Potter
text: But there was nothing to be seen.

author: Potter
text: They returned to the kitchen.

author: Potter
text: "Here's one of your kittens at least," said Ribby, dragging Moppet out of the flour barrel.

author: Potter
text: They shook the flour off her and set her down on the kitchen floor.

author: Potter
text: She seemed to be in a terrible fright.

author: Potter
text: "Oh!

author: Potter
text: Mother, Mother," said Moppet, "there's been an old woman rat in the kitchen, and she's stolen some of the dough!"

author: Potter
text: The two cats ran to look at the dough pan.

author: Potter
text: Sure enough there were marks of little scratching fingers, and a lump of dough was gone!

author: Potter
text: "Which way did she go, Moppet?"

author: Potter
text: But Moppet had been too much frightened to peep out of the barrel again.

author: Potter
text: Ribby and Tabitha took her with them to keep her safely in sight, while they went on with their search.

author: Potter
text: They went into the dairy.

author: Potter
text: The first thing they found was Mittens, hiding in an empty jar.

author: Potter
text: They tipped over the jar, and she scrambled out.

author: Potter
text: "Oh, Mother, Mother!" said Mittens--

author: Potter
text: "Oh!

author: Potter
text: Mother, Mother, there has been an old man rat in the dairy--a dreadful 'normous big rat, Mother; and he's stolen a pat of butter and the rolling pin."

author: Potter
text: Ribby and Tabitha looked at one another.

author: Potter
text: "A rolling pin and butter!

author: Potter
text: Oh, my poor son Thomas!" exclaimed Tabitha, wringing her paws.

author: Potter
text: "A rolling pin?" said Ribby.

author: Potter
text: "Did we not hear a roly-poly noise in the attic when we were looking into that chest?"

author: Potter
text: Ribby and Tabitha rushed upstairs again.

author: Potter
text: Sure enough the roly-poly noise was still going on quite distinctly under the attic floor.

author: Potter
text: "This is serious, Cousin Tabitha," said Ribby.

author: Potter
text: "We must send for John Joiner at once, with a saw."

author: Potter
text: Now, this is what had been happening to Tom Kitten, and it shows how very unwise it is to go up a chimney in a very old house, where a person does not know his way, and where there are enormous rats.

author: Potter
text: Tom Kitten did not want to be shut up in a cupboard.

author: Potter
text: When he saw that his mother was going to bake, he determined to hide.

author: Potter
text: He looked about for a nice convenient place, and he fixed upon the chimney.

author: Potter
text: The fire had only just been lighted, and it was not hot; but there was a white choky smoke from the green sticks.

author: Potter
text: Tom Kitten got upon the fender and looked up.

author: Potter
text: It was a big old- fashioned fireplace.

author: Potter
text: The chimney itself was wide enough inside for a man to stand up and walk about.

author: Potter
text: So there was plenty of room for a little Tom Cat.

author: Potter
text: He jumped right up into the fireplace, balancing himself upon the iron bar where the kettle hangs.

author: Potter
text: Tom Kitten took another big jump off the bar and landed on a ledge high up inside the chimney, knocking down some soot into the fender.

author: Potter
text: Tom Kitten coughed and choked with the smoke; he could hear the sticks beginning to crackle and burn in the fireplace down below.

author: Potter
text: He made up his mind to climb right to the top, and get out on the slates, and try to catch sparrows.

author: Potter
text: "I cannot go back.

author: Potter
text: If I slipped I might fall in the fire and singe my beautiful tail and my little blue jacket."

author: Potter
text: The chimney was a very big old- fashioned one.

author: Potter
text: It was built in the days when people burnt logs of wood upon the hearth.

author: Potter
text: The chimney stack stood up above the roof like a little stone tower, and the daylight shone down from the top, under the slanting slates that kept out the rain.

author: Potter
text: Tom Kitten was getting very frightened!

author: Potter
text: He climbed up, and up, and up.

author: Potter
text: Then he waded sideways through inches of soot.

author: Potter
text: He was like a little sweep himself.

author: Potter
text: It was most confusing in the dark.

author: Potter
text: One flue seemed to lead into another.

author: Potter
text: There was less smoke, but Tom Kitten felt quite lost.

author: Potter
text: He scrambled up and up; but before he reached the chimney top he came to a place where somebody had loosened a stone in the wall.

author: Potter
text: There were some mutton bones lying about.

author: Potter
text: "This seems funny," said Tom Kitten.

author: Potter
text: "Who has been gnawing bones up here in the chimney?

author: Potter
text: I wish I had never come!

author: Potter
text: And what a funny smell?

author: Potter
text: It is something like mouse, only dreadfully strong.

author: Potter
text: It makes me sneeze," said Tom Kitten.

author: Potter
text: He squeezed through the hole in the wall and dragged himself along a most uncomfortably tight passage where there was scarcely any light.

author: Potter
text: He groped his way carefully for several yards; he was at the back of the skirting board in the attic, where there is a little mark * in the picture.

author: Potter
text: All at once he fell head over heels in the dark, down a hole, and landed on a heap of very dirty rags.

author: Potter
text: When Tom Kitten picked himself up and looked about him, he found himself in a place that he had never seen before, although he had lived all his life in the house.

author: Potter
text: It was a very small stuffy fusty room, with boards, and rafters, and cobwebs, and lath and plaster.

author: Potter
text: Opposite to him--as far away as he could sit--was an enormous rat.

author: Potter
text: "What do you mean by tumbling into my bed all covered with smuts?" said the rat, chattering his teeth.

author: Potter
text: "Please, sir, the chimney wants sweeping," said poor Tom Kitten.

author: Potter
text: "Anna Maria!

author: Potter
text: Anna Maria!" squeaked the rat.

author: Potter
text: There was a pattering noise and an old woman rat poked her head round a rafter.

author: Potter
text: All in a minute she rushed upon Tom Kitten, and before he knew what was happening.

author: Potter
text: . . . his coat was pulled off, and he was rolled up in a bundle, and tied with string in very hard knots.

author: Potter
text: Anna Maria did the tying.

author: Potter
text: The old rat watched her and took snuff.

author: Potter
text: When she had finished, they both sat staring at him with their mouths open.

author: Potter
text: "Anna Maria," said the old man rat (whose name was Samuel Whiskers), "Anna Maria, make me a kitten dumpling roly-poly pudding for my dinner."

author: Potter
text: "It requires dough and a pat of butter and a rolling pin," said Anna Maria, considering Tom Kitten with her head on one side.

author: Potter
text: "No," said Samuel Whiskers, "make it properly, Anna Maria, with breadcrumbs."

author: Potter
text: "Nonsense!

author: Potter
text: Butter and dough," replied Anna Maria.

author: Potter
text: The two rats consulted together for a few minutes and then went away.

author: Potter
text: Samuel Whiskers got through a hole in the wainscot and went boldly down the front staircase to the dairy to get the butter.

author: Potter
text: He did not meet anybody.

author: Potter
text: He made a second journey for the rolling pin.

author: Potter
text: He pushed it in front of him with his paws, like a brewer's man trundling a barrel.

author: Potter
text: He could hear Ribby and Tabitha talking, but they were too busy lighting the candle to look into the chest.

author: Potter
text: They did not see him.

author: Potter
text: Anna Maria went down by way of skirting board and a window shutter to the kitchen to steal the dough.

author: Potter
text: She borrowed a small saucer and scooped up the dough with her paws.

author: Potter
text: She did not observe Moppet.

author: Potter
text: While Tom Kitten was left alone under the floor of the attic, he wriggled about and tried to mew for help.

author: Potter
text: But his mouth was full of soot and cobwebs, and he was tied up in such very tight knots, he could not make anybody hear him.

author: Potter
text: Except a spider who came out of a crack in the ceiling and examined the knots critically, from a safe distance.

author: Potter
text: It was a judge of knots because it had a habit of tying up unfortunate bluebottles.

author: Potter
text: It did not offer to assist him.

author: Potter
text: Tom Kitten wriggled and squirmed until he was quite exhausted.

author: Potter
text: Presently the rats came back and set to work to make him into a dumpling.

author: Potter
text: First they smeared him with butter, and then they rolled him in the dough.

author: Potter
text: "Will not the string be very indigestible, Anna Maria?" inquired Samuel Whiskers.

author: Potter
text: Anna Maria said she thought that it was of no consequence; but she wished that Tom Kitten would hold his head still, as it disarranged the pastry.

author: Potter
text: She laid hold of his ears.

author: Potter
text: Tom Kitten bit and spit, and mewed and wriggled; and the rolling pin went roly-poly, roly; roly-poly, roly.

author: Potter
text: The rats each held an end.

author: Potter
text: "His tail is sticking out!

author: Potter
text: You did not fetch enough dough, Anna Maria."

author: Potter
text: "I fetched as much as I could carry," replied Anna Maria.

author: Potter
text: "I do not think"--said Samuel Whiskers, pausing to take a look at Tom Kitten--"I do NOT think it will be a good pudding.

author: Potter
text: It smells sooty."

author: Potter
text: Anna Maria was about to argue the point when all at once there began to be other sounds up above--the rasping noise of a saw, and the noise of a little dog, scratching and yelping!

author: Potter
text: The rats dropped the rolling pin and listened attentively.

author: Potter
text: "We are discovered and interrupted, Anna Maria; let us collect our property--and other people's--and depart at once.

author: Potter
text: "I fear that we shall be obliged to leave this pudding.

author: Potter
text: "But I am persuaded that the knots would have proved indigestible, whatever you may urge to the contrary."

author: Potter
text: "Come away at once and help me to tie up some mutton bones in a counterpane," said Anna Maria.

author: Potter
text: "I have got half a smoked ham hidden in the chimney."

author: Potter
text: So it happened that by the time John Joiner had got the plank up-- there was nobody here under the floor except the rolling pin and Tom Kitten in a very dirty dumpling!

author: Potter
text: But there was a strong smell of rats; and John Joiner spent the rest of the morning sniffing and whining, and wagging his tail, and going round and round with his head in the hole like a gimlet.

author: Potter
text: Then he nailed the plank down again and put his tools in his bag, and came downstairs.

author: Potter
text: The cat family had quite recovered.

author: Potter
text: They invited him to stay to dinner.

author: Potter
text: The dumpling had been peeled off Tom Kitten and made separately into a bag pudding, with currants in it to hide the smuts.

author: Potter
text: They had been obliged to put Tom Kitten into a hot bath to get the butter off.

author: Potter
text: John Joiner smelt the pudding; but he regretted that he had not time to stay to dinner, because he had just finished making a wheelbarrow for Miss Potter, and she had ordered two hen coops.

author: Potter
text: And when I was going to the post late in the afternoon--I looked up the land from the corner, and I saw Mr. Samuel Whiskers and his wife on the run, with big bundles on a little wheelbarrow, which looked very much like mine.

author: Potter
text: They were just turning in at the gate to the barn of Farmer Potatoes.

author: Potter
text: Samuel Whiskers was puffing and out of breath.

author: Potter
text: Anna Maria was still arguing in shrill tones.

author: Potter
text: She seemed to know her way, and she seemed to have a quantity of luggage.

author: Potter
text: I am sure _I_ never gave her leave to borrow my wheelbarrow!

author: Potter
text: They went into the barn and hauled their parcels with a bit of string to the top of the haymow.

author: Potter
text: After that, there were no more rats for a long time at Tabitha Twitchit's.

author: Potter
text: As for Farmer Potatoes, he has been driven nearly distracted.

author: Potter
text: There are rats, and rats, and rats in his barn!

author: Potter
text: They eat up the chicken food, and steal the oats and bran, and make holes in the meal bags.

author: Potter
text: And they are all descended from Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Whiskers-- children and grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren.

author: Potter
text: There is no end to them!

author: Potter
text: Moppet and Mittens have grown up into very good rat-catchers.

author: Potter
text: They go out rat-catching in the village, and they find plenty of employment.

author: Potter
text: They charge so much a dozen and earn their living very comfortably.

author: Potter
text: They hang up the rats' tails in a row on the barn door, to show how many they have caught--dozens and dozens of them.

author: Potter
text: But Tom Kitten has always been afraid of a rat; he never durst face anything that is bigger than--

author: Potter
text: A Mouse.
